structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course covers the key political, economic and security issues of the EU-Russia relations against a broad empirical background of official documents and wider public debates. It discusses the actors' identities, history of EU-Russia relations since the collapse of the Soviet Union, institutional frameworks, bilateral as well as multilateral, issues of path-dependence in the lead-up to the 2014 crisis and the main items on the current agenda. The latter include the sanctions, security, memory, trade and energy, and people-to-people contacts. During the seminar sessions, the discussion is organised around contemporary sources representing the controversies that defined the parties' standing and the political outcomes.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb põhilisi poliitilisi, majanduslikke ning julgeolekualalisi probleeme EL-Venemaa suhetes; taustaks on nii ametlikud dokumendid kui ka avalikud debatid. Arutatakse EL ja Venemaa identiteete, nende suhete ajalugu alatest NL lagunemisest, kahe- ja mitmepoolseid institutsioone, 2014. a. kriisi põhjusi ning kaasaegseid küsimusi.

objectives.en: The course provides an overview of the agenda of EU-Russia relations, reviews their history, institutional foundations analyses the key factors shaping the patterns of both high-profile conflict and low-key cooperation.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on anda ülevaade Euroopa Liidu ja Venemaa poliitilistest- ja majandussuhetest ning analüüsida peamisi faktoreid, mis neid suhteid määravad.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completing the course, the students will be able to:
1)	understand the key problems defining the agenda of the relations between the EU and Russia;
2)	relate specific issues of EU-Russia relations to main ideological and theoretical paradigms and be able to critically re-assess the origins and background of specific political discourses;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab seostada EL-Venemaa suhete seisu teoreetiliste paradigmadega ning mõista erinevaid tõlgendusvõimalusi;

learning_outcomes.en: 3)	use most important sources of information and documents in the field of EU-Russia relations;
learning_outcomes.et: - on võimeline kasutama tähtsamaid allikaid ja dokumente EL-Venemaa suhete alal;

learning_outcomes.en: 4)	be able to use this knowledge by participating in an informed and constructive debate on all aspects of EU-Russia relations.
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab hinnata erinevaid normatiivseid aluseid EL-Vene suhete konfliktsuses tulenevalt Euroopa ideest ja tuleviku maailmakorra üle käivatest debattidest.

notes.et: The course is taught with the support of the Jean Monnet module on The EU's Engagement with Russia and post-Soviet neighbors (EURUPN).

independent_work.et:
The students are expected to complete compulsory readings before each class.
It is strongly recommended that the students follow the current political developments in the EU and Russia, using major international news outlets.

description.et: Students will be asked to sign up for one of working groups (WG) that will be requested to present in-depth policy analysis of a certain problem, situation or controversy in the realm of EU-Russian relations. Results of each case study analysis will be presented in the form of expert panel. The quality of each of them will be judged on the basis of comprehensive engagement with the recommended sources of information and the ability to make independent conclusions on the basis of critical thinking.

grade_preconditions.et: In order to receive final grade, the students must attend at least 70% of all classes, and complete all compulsory assignments.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade for the course is based on the following components:
- case analysis in Working Groups (5o% of the total grade)
- final multiple choice test (50% of the total grade)

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials: All reading materials are available in SIS.
resources.recommended_materials: All reading materials are available in SIS.

description.et:
Guest lecture by Sabine Selchow (LSE) on EU Global Strategy, followed by expert panel on EU-Russia Relations in a wider Europe (part of the annual winter school "People and Territories").
Room 215, 12:00 - 14:30

Introduction to the course. Course structure, main concepts in EU - Russia studies. 
Approaches to EU-Russia relations and research puzzles
Trajectories and Nodal Points of EU-Russia Relations: 1991-2018
The EU as a liberal normative power: the transformative potential and its limits

EU Security Policies
Case study: cyber-security (guest lecturer: Alex Hardy, University of London)
Populism(s) and Euroscepticism(s): a Challenge / Alternative to the EU
Case study: Estonia in the Context of EU-Russian Conflict
Russia's Illiberal Backlash: European Dimensions (discourses and policy practices)
The EU and Russia in the Baltic Sea Region: What Went Wrong with Region-making?
The EU-Russia Trans-border Relations / Interactions: a Sub-national Perspective

Guest lecture: Dr. Adrien Fauve, Universite Paris Sud
"French Diplomacy in the Russian - Georgian Conflict of August 2008"
Summing up and looking ahead: lessons learned

audience.et: Students of Johan Skytte institute of Political Studies and wider audience interested in EU-Russia relations
